major issue: I don't think you should start with coders and work out :smile:

elements.text: major issue: I don't think you should start with coders and work out

text: I want to prioritise an article where you jump right in and show us what it actually is like to use

elements.text: I want to prioritise an article where you jump right in and show us what it actually is like to use

text: Interesting about coders and working out. Why doesn’t that sound good?

elements.text: Interesting about coders and working out. Why doesn’t that sound good?

text: (fixed the typo, thanks!)

elements.text: (fixed the typo, thanks!)

text: I've spent my whole life trying to fit my ideas in to the constraints of what coders expect

elements.text: I've spent my whole life trying to fit my ideas in to the constraints of what coders expect

text: I've now officially given up, and the freedom is like fresh air

elements.text: I've now officially given up, and the freedom is like fresh air

text: (I think <@U6KQ2S410> has also had a similar experience)

elements.text: (I think
has also had a similar experience)

text: speaking as a professional JS coder, though, Dark sounds like it's addressing all the pain I experience at work, so let's hope it's the next big thing in professional coding!

elements.text: speaking as a professional JS coder, though, Dark sounds like it's addressing all the pain I experience at work, so let's hope it's the next big thing in professional coding!

text: just don't think you can start there and end up with non-coders using it.

elements.text: just don't think you can start there and end up with non-coders using it.

text: So i think that makes sense if you’re not approaching it from a commercial point of view. We’re taking a fiercely pragmatic approach, which is that devs are gatekeepers and fashion forward leaders for this type of tech (that is, one that can be used to solve broad existing problems)

elements.text: So i think that makes sense if you’re not approaching it from a commercial point of view. We’re taking a fiercely pragmatic approach, which is that devs are gatekeepers and fashion forward leaders for this type of tech (that is, one that can be used to solve broad existing problems)

text: Also, I’ve gotten pretty good at figuring out how to sell/market to devs over the last few years :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Also, I’ve gotten pretty good at figuring out how to sell/market to devs over the last few years

text: OK :smile:

elements.text: OK

text:
Great stuff!

>  Combining a database with its application removes many questions that neither component can answer by itself, such as what indexes are needed, how to shard, the best way to write queries, and how to manage long-running data migrations.

Strongly agree! The holistic approach in Dark is very appealing. Much of the work these days is hand wiring to tie impedance mismatched systems together, with pervasive model duplication. Looks like Dark is going with 'one model' system wide. Reminds me of Jos Jong's Vertically Integrated Architectures book.

elements.text: Great stuff!

Combining a database with its application removes many questions that neither component can answer by itself, such as what indexes are needed, how to shard, the best way to write queries, and how to manage long-running data migrations.

Strongly agree! The holistic approach in Dark is very appealing. Much of the work these days is hand wiring to tie impedance mismatched systems together, with pervasive model duplication. Looks like Dark is going with 'one model' system wide. Reminds me of Jos Jong's Vertically Integrated Architectures book.

text: Yes! There’s still model duplication between frontend and backend, but I expect to allow deriving frontend models from backend types at some point.

elements.text: Yes! There’s still model duplication between frontend and backend, but I expect to allow deriving frontend models from backend types at some point.

text: Interesting. How does versioning work? Is there one versioning system for code, schema and data?

elements.text: Interesting. How does versioning work? Is there one versioning system for code, schema and data?

text: We haven’t got it fully worked out yet, but we think it’ll basically be feature flags (a FF is a new version in the UI). Also, versioning is kinda different - it’s not used for shipping or merging, just a historical record of how things were).

elements.text: We haven’t got it fully worked out yet, but we think it’ll basically be feature flags (a FF is a new version in the UI). Also, versioning is kinda different - it’s not used for shipping or merging, just a historical record of how things were).

text: I see. Might be useful to have a knob to ramp up slowly.

elements.text: I see. Might be useful to have a knob to ramp up slowly.

text: That was the first version we tried. However, at the start people have such low volume that they actually want fine-grained user controls (mainly: is this user me). We think the other major use is “run both and report differences”, and that ramp up slowly will come later

elements.text: That was the first version we tried. However, at the start people have such low volume that they actually want fine-grained user controls (mainly: is this user me). We think the other major use is “run both and report differences”, and that ramp up slowly will come later

text: <@U6BRN7A0Y> I've been following the progress of Darklang. How much would this language affect frontend development? Would that have to be done in the same language? Would I be able to use JS? If not, how would you address lacking support from the ecosystem?

elements.text: I've been following the progress of Darklang. How much would this language affect frontend development? Would that have to be done in the same language? Would I be able to use JS? If not, how would you address lacking support from the ecosystem?

text: You would do frontend as you do now, using the same languages

elements.text: You would do frontend as you do now, using the same languages

text: We have apps written in Reason, React, ReactNative, and Elm, all using Dark.

elements.text: We have apps written in Reason, React, ReactNative, and Elm, all using Dark.

elements.text: And swift and android java
